Evaluation.explanation: The candidate lists a variety of languages, frameworks, and tools, showing a good breadth of technical skills. The depth in each is not fully clear from the CV alone, but the projects and experience sections provide some evidence of practical application. Strong skills include C++, C#, Java, Python, Unity, Qt5, Spring Boot, Django, Git, MySQL, and PostgreSQL. The candidate demonstrates understanding of various languages and Frameworks in the field. They list SFML as a Library. There is no mention of cloud services or DevOps tools.

The projects section highlights problem-solving skills. For example, the Parser & Computer Algebra System (CAS) project demonstrates the ability to handle complex mathematical expressions and implement simplification algorithms. The Underwater Physic Engine and Microscopic Traffic Simulator also involve problem-solving in physics and traffic simulation. The descriptions provided are concise, but they show evidence of tackling moderately complex problems. The experience at FPT suggests the ability to address problems related to API development and authentication.

The CV mentions experience as a Programming Mentor, suggesting good communication skills for explaining technical concepts to students. The description includes creating bilingual lesson plans. The Software Development Intern role implies collaboration within a team, but specific details on collaboration are lacking. Clear and concise descriptions in the project sections are also a plus.

The range of projects and skills listed suggests adaptability and a willingness to learn new technologies. The candidate has experience with different languages (C++, C#, Java, Python) and frameworks (Unity, Qt5, Spring Boot, Django), indicating adaptability. The projects also indicate they are a quick learner, due to the variety of technologies used to develop them. The CV does not mention contributions to open source projects or any involvement in recent technologies.

The CV mentions experience with SFML (Simple and Fast Multimedia Library), used in some projects like Parser & Computer Algebra System. While this is not a traditional front-end framework for web development, it shows experience in graphics and UI. There is no explicit mention of HTML, CSS, or JavaScript. The Graph Drawer project in C# and Unity suggests experience with GUI development, but lacks the key front-end web skills.

The candidate has experience with Spring Boot, Django, Java, Python, PostgreSQL, and MySQL, all of which are backend technologies. The internship involved developing RESTful APIs using Spring MVC and implementing authentication/authorization systems. This demonstrates solid backend development skills. The CV effectively shows experience with back-end development technologies.

The candidate has experience developing RESTful APIs during their internship. This indicates a practical understanding of web services and API design. The description mentions handling datasets using PostgreSQL and MySQL which means they have the ability to retrieve and manipulate data from a database through their APIs.

The candidate lists Git under Developer Tools, suggesting familiarity with version control. However, the CV lacks specific details about branching strategies, merging, or conflict resolution. They might have some knowledge of Git, but the CV lacks specifics.

The candidate lists MySQL and PostgreSQL under Developer Tools and mentions using them in their internship. This shows familiarity with database management systems. The description mentions handling datasets, implying experience with querying and data manipulation. The degree of optimization experience is not clear.
